text:
(On tap @ Anvil and Stave, April 5/17) Pours a deep red tinged brown with a stable fine white head. Aroma is dried figs, toffee, grapes, vanilla, bourbon. Flavour mimics it a bunch, rich toffee, figs, vanilla, mixed dried fruit, some whiskey, light heat, oak. A bit nutty. Pretty balanced for the abv. Medium full body and soft carb. 
A textbook high-quality bourbon barrel barley wine.

On tap at Anvil & Stave. Pours a very dark brown with light head. Aromas of sweet roasted malts, caramel, dry bourbon and hint of fruit. Flavors of same with a little more bourbon ABV.
Very nice.
On tap at Anvil & Stave. Dark brown with a small head. Sweet with dried fruit, toffee, vanilla, bourbon and malt. The body was full and the mouthfeel fairly relaxed. A nice one to sip.
Pours a murky light brown faint around the rim lacing. The aroma is heavy caramel, vanilla, chocolate coffee bourbon, toffee figs and raisins. Flavor is sweet but not cloying

Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle poured into a snifter. Clear light brown with small white head. Aroma is caramel, medium body, low carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is caramel malt, bourbon, some wood, and a little alcohol.
Pours hazy dark brown with a thin light tanned head. Aroma; Vanilla, bourbon, toffee and oak. Taste; Bourbon, vanilla, toffee, almond and a touch of dried dark fruits.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.
A: Deep brown coloured with some red notes and a huge offwhite head N: Bourbon, vanilla, oak, toffee, tobacco T: Bourbon, vanilla, toffee O: Very nice balanced!
UPDATED: OCT 20, 2016 Bottle at tasting panel at Warszawski festiwal piwa. Very complex, nice balance, full of almond, vanilla, ripe and dark fruits. One of best.

750ml bottle pours out amber topped with a small sand head. Nose is nice sweetness malts toffee brown sugar some pit fruit and some of the bourbon barrel vanilla shows. Taste is more of the sweet malt caramel toffee pitfruit and the bourbon barrel goodness.

Bottle from last nights share. Thick amber body, small ring of bubbly head, Picking up all of the barley wine essences, but little of the bourbon barrel. Sweet malt, toffee, caramel in both aroma and taste. It doesnt even present itself as that boozy of a beer. Some dark fruit, raisins, some vanilla.

Tapped at the epic Alesmith barrel aged beer tasting room. Dark brown color, red orange when flash lighted. Beige thick head. Taste is epic refreshing fruity plums strawberry cherries grapes. Finish is epic dry tabaco cigar like taste. Impressive! I have never tasted a cigar in a beer. Epic. Overall mind blowing!
On draft at the brewerry. Pours a murky mahogany with a tan head. Fruity nose. Flavors of caramel, bourbon, vanilla and oak. Boozy roast finish.

750ml bottle from Saveur-Biere. Oravankolo tasting. Vintage 2013.


Reddish hazy colour. Bourbon, warmness, dark fruits, plum, raisin, boozy breath. Mmm..

750 ml bottle. 2016 vintage. Just picked this one up from the brewery last weekend. The beer is a dark amber brown. Small light brown to beige head. Deep toasty malt flavors. Big caramel. Treacle, molasses, brown sugar. Vanilla, coconut, caramel in bourbon barrel flavors. The barrel is well-integrated and goes with the beer nicely. Taste is rich and sweet. Lots of toasty malt. Big barrel sweetness. Light woody bitterness. Fairly strong booze, but its nice and warming. Full body. Fairly smooth. Relatively thick. Very nice beer.
Draft. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Rich bourbon, molasses, vanilla, and a good dose of sweetness throughout. A big beer, for sure, but relatively well balanced, and not over barreled.

A huge thanks to Michael for this awesome offering! Liquide sombre dallure de vieux Cognac, sans mousse, reflets caramélisés, rubis, orangés. Robe dune sublimissime profondeur! Des arômes de caramel vanillé, de mélasse, dorange, de fruits noirs, dorge maltée. Cest profond, cest riche. Jadore! Une bouffée de chaleur sempare de moi lorsque glisse dans ma bouche la première gorgée. Limpression d,un doux caramel chaud me tapisser loesophage st loin dêtre déplaisante! Un cristal de sucre y demeure toutefois collé, mais je choisis de me moquer de lui. Je suis envoûté par cette douce vanille à la profondeur du bourbon, par cette prouesse agricole issue dune terre fertile et grasse, par ce savoir-faire brassicole qui repousse encore les limites de ce style qui me bouleverse.

August 29, 2015. Bottle at home, vintage 2012, received in a trade with AtlCarl, thanks! 
Light hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty, vanilla, bourbon, toffee, figs, some toasted oak with hints of coconut. Taste is sweet malty, light bitter, some light boozy warming notes. Finish is warming bourbon notes, sweet toffee, caramel, figs, some raisins, vanilla, some bitter notes of hops and charred oak. Medium to full bodied with creamy oily texture, soft carbonation. 
Very nice malty barley wine with great barrel character.

2012 bottle thanks to Gibson. Pours a cloudy brown with beige head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is burnt sugar, bourbon, wood. Thick body, chewy, roast, bourbon, vanilla, burnt sugar, really enjoyed this.
BH7 tasting, 2005 bottle, murky brown, light caramel and bourbon nose, smooth bodied, bourbon notes, no char or wood, caramel, maple syrup, lighter finish than expected.

10 year old bottle shared by alexsdad06 pour copper brown with minimal tan head. Nose caramel, toffee, raisin, sweeter character from Bourbon, minimal oxidation. Taste sweeter malt up front, prune, molasses, then caramel, light cherry /vanilla from the barrel. Minimal oxidation. Drinks pretty nice for 10 year old.

Bottle. Vintage 2012 acquired many moons ago, sampled side by side with the rye version. Appearance is dark brown with frothy white head. Aroma is vanilla, brown sugar, and charred oak. Taste is a hint of pine, brown sugar, vanilla and oak. Smooth finish, with no hint of booze. Really nice, lots of barrel character but I still get some nice piney undertones from the base beer.
Deep red wine with white head. Complex bourbon, vanilla, herbal and spicy. Sweet, slick and lingering bourbon finish. Overall: the bourbon is incredible well implemented. Cosy-fire-place-deluxe

Aromas of caramel, bread, banana, malts, slight hoppy spicy character but mainly big malts, raisins and barrel. Taste is full with big dark fruits, grains and hints of boozy barrel. Very rounded. Sweet but not too much. A slow sipper. Lovely big barley wine with a full mouthfeel and soft carbonation.

Absolute treat for a barleywine! Aged in bottle for over a year. Pronounced bourbon on the aroma with vanilla and wood dominating. Malty and chewy body with warming alcohol finish. Perfectly balanced in terms of all relevant taste dimensions, sweetness, bitterness, and alcohol heat. Definitely worth getting your hands on this beer.

750ml bottle of 2013 release. Pours a brown color with a bit of head. Bourbon aroma when the cap came off. Rich caramel flavors. The bourbon overpowers a little at first but the. Balances nicely with some time to breathe. Some plum notes.

75cl bottle served in a snifter. Pours deep garnet with a very short lived off white film of bubbles. Aroma is pure bourbon with vanilla, coconut, chocolate and any many of sweet delicacies you care to imagine. Taste is upfront vanilla with the thick mouthfeel and complex flavour profile of the standard Old Numbskull but with out the hops and in place a smorgasbord of marron glace, apricots, chocolate, vanilla and a warming alcohol hit but very subdued and not overly hot. Perfectly judged and all flavours complement each other whilst being powerful they are never overpowering. So mellow and smooth but at the same time a real sipper and one to savour (which at this price is a blessing in disguise). Perfect barley wine.

Excelentes notas aromáticas. Destacan los aromas a frutos secos, principalmente pasas e higos. En segunda instancia se perciben notas maltosas y el Bourbon.

Color café ligeramente cobrizo y algo turbio. Cuerpo redondo, Corona de espuma media de baja retención. Carbonatacion baja.

En boca es dulce, con buen equilibrio final y bastante frutal.

Al paladar es una cerveza sumamente compleja, y de igual forma deliciosa.
Bastante maltosa y con notas dulces, sin embargo con un buen equilibrio amargo al final.
Sumamente frutal, en dónde las pasas, ciruelas, dátiles e higos secos dominan.
Al retrogusto se perciben las notas al Bourbon sin ser excesivas así como naturalmente el alcohol.

En resumen es una cerveza excepcional, exquisita y a la vez sumamente compleja.
Barleywine de la mejor calidad y excelentemente bien lograda.
Bomber to a taster. Opaque brown with tan head. Sweet toffee notes with vanilla and bourbon... Smooth boozy finish... Delicious!!!
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; dark copper brown pour with a thin tan head, aroma has strong bourbon and dark cherry, taste has boozy bourbon, sweet caramel, vanilla, dark malts, some molasses.
Bottle at Dangerous Bottleshares WHLZBRZ edition. Dark amber pour with an off white head. Notes of toffee, caramel, bourbon, butterscotch, figs, nuts, plums and some malty sweetness.

Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshares WLZBRZ edition. Pours dark reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma of oxidized plums, caramel, sweet bourbon, butterscotch, dark sweet malts and weak chocolate. Very nice and mellow sweet aroma. The taste has some sweet and hot bourbon, some plums, ripe darker fruits, faded bold hops is there as well along with some malty caramel notes. A tad hot but still delicate!

750ml bottle enjoyed @ Dangerous Bottleshares - WHLZBRZ-edition. Pours murky brown with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is lots of bourbon, caramel, dark dried fruits, vanilla and chocolate. Flavour is medium sweet and medium bitter. Full bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation. Finish is boozy bourbon.
Pours burgundy-ish brown with a modest brown head. Aroma is caramel, pine, slight earthiness. Taste is caramel, fudge, slight heat, fudge. Full bodied.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2015 Bottle at Dangerous Bottleshares WHLZBRZ-edition. Pours hazy dark brown with a medium offwhite head. Aromas of lots of bourbon, fudge, toffee, vanilla, chocolate, malt, caramel, light hoppy, dark fruits, sweet orange. Taste is a huge bourbon bomb with lots of caramel and vanilla, some nutty notes, fudge, chocolate, light booze, dark sweet fruits, slight hops in the backend with some sweeter citrus fruits.

Barley wine rating #50! Bottle 75cl at Dangerous Bottleshares WHLZBRZ edition. Pours a hazy, rusty amber with a medium sized, off white head. Aroma has looots of bourbon! Vanilla, coco nut, fudge, caramel, still some fruity hops, lots of figs, dates and prunes. Taste is sweet with vanilla, lots of dried fruits, fudgy caramel, boozy bourbon, slight hoppy finish. Average carbonation and a full, sticky body. Great barley wine!

Aroma: Dark berries, malt, chocolate and bourbon. 
Flavour: Fruity sweet and bitter with notes of plumbs, caramel and bourbon. A creamy mouthfeel and an alcoholic warmth.
Colour: Reddish brown with an offwhite head. 
From: Taster @ Volby Ølmesse August 2015

Bottle. Pours an all dark brown with creamy beige head. Aroma is a bourbon bomb. Packed with toffee, vanilla, coconut, so rich, coffee, chocolate, toast, prunes, dark fruits. This beer is all changed. Taste is like drinking bourbon without the booze. Vanilla, wood, coconut, dark fruits, toffee, caramel, light bitter chocolate, burnt malts. Full body, toasty finish, very subtle hops. Just very well executed and drinkable. Warming feel.
Brown coloured and clear. Has an off-white head, medium duration. Nice sweet aroma, roasted sugars, yeasty, toffee. Flavor is melow, soft, lots of flavors, toasted.
heavy sweet malty aroma,brown, off white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice heavy sweet barrel finish.

Bottle. Hazy dark amber with small beige head. Aroma is malt, dark fruit, bourbon, vanilla, toasted and oak. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, oak, wood, bourbon, sweet, hop, little bitter, warming, little coconut and a little bitter.

Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Hazy reddish brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, wood, vanilla and bourbon. Flavor is very sweet and rather bitter. Sweet and rather bitter finish with lots of warming alcohol. 241015
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are rich bourbon, caramel, vanilla, fruits, hops, candy sugar, wood and has a nice sweet finish. Full bodied.

Bottle. Dark brown in color with an off-white head. Oaky wooden notes, some fruityness and vanilla too in aroma. Some sweeter notes such as toffee appears later on together with some malty vibes. Nice indeed. Wood, vanilla and toffee in taste. Smooth one. Bourbon and dried fruityness in the end. A warmer even if you hardly notice the abv here. Good brew.

Bottle @ Voldby Øl-messe. Pours dark amber with a small offwhite head. Aroma of rich malt, caramel, toffee, sweet dark fruits, oak, vanilla, coconut notes, bourbon. Flavor is light sweet, malty, caramel, sweet dark fruits, plums, light tart wood, oak, vanilla, bourbon, light alcohol. Medium body, oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation, light sweet finish with warming alcohol. 290815
Bottle@ølmesse, Voldby (29-08-15). Pours dark amber with a tan head. Aroma and taste is roasted malt, dark fruit, caramel, toffee, chocolate notes, bourbon. Oily mouthfeel. Soft carbonation.

Bottle. Thanks hackobock! Light hazy deep ruby liquid with medium light tan head. Aroma of vanilla, raw sugar, toffee, bourbon, oak, caramel and dried fruit. Super nice aroma. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with notes of raw sugar, raisins, toffee, oak and bourbon. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nice, but body could be thicker.
Dark auburn. Nose is figs, cardboard, honey, booze, vanilla. Taste is booze, veggies, paper, figs. Sticky mouthfeel.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Sweet malts, vanilla, bourbon aromas. Sweet chocolate, vanilla, bourbon and oak flavors.

750 ml bottle shared with Spencer, Gus, and Eric. Vintage 2012. The pour is a dark reddish brown with a thin light tan head and no lace. The aroma is beautiful. Good caramel and a light booze. The malts are incredible. The flavor is much of the same. There is a light vanilla and oak with a beautiful toffee and light booze presence. The mouth feel is a little light with a nice maltiness a and a good booziness. The aftertaste is lingeringly malty and caramel and delicious. This is a great beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with koleminer20. 2012 vintage. Aroma is dark fruit, booze, malt, caramel, toffee, nice. Appearance is brown, light brown head. Taste is balanced, figs, caramel, toffee, booze, fantastic. Mouthfeel is thick, boozy, great carbonation, long-lasting flavor. Overall, this is a wonderful representation of the style.
Very bourbony smell with butterscotch. Thick sticky mouthfeel but has a little alcohol heat to it. Taste is caramel, butterscotch, and heavy bourbon.

Not sure why this one kept getting passed over at the bottle sharing at the R bSG but I ended up,with most of the bottle. Poured jet black with no head. Nose of ripe fruit and bourbon notes. Bold in body with a c,lean though somewhat alcoholic mouth feel.

Bottle at catch 22 bottle share! Pours a deep golden brown with minimal tan head. Aroma is big on the barrel and sweetness. Taste follows, but not as good as brandy, super hoppy still. Overall an awesome brew for sure, booze is well hidden or l was already drunk at this point.

Bottle, shared with Parksy, phantomhennes, heavylaevy, and TvM. 2005 Vintage. This beer was the official first brew to toast our new home in Desert Blume! Murky amber with golden highlights, chunky beige head. Aroma is very rich, brothy and bready with sweet bourbon undertones. The palate delivers thick chewy malt structure, bread and brown sugar, notes of vanilla, oak, and a touch of leather and spice. No hint of the ABV. Heavy and rich but with a dry finish. The bourbon is almost hidden in the rich malts, which serves this beer well. Just fantastic.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: This is how Im celebrating my 4000th rating. Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber color with a reddish tinge and a moderate light tan head on there. Nose has some nice grains and caramel to it, with the bourbon providing a nice complement over top without dominating. Taste is actually pretty dry, with barley coming through and a dry bourbony bite. Super warming, yet subtle. Great brew.

[2/19/15] Bottle at the hotel in San Diego. Thanks Tom L. Bottle broke in Toms bag, but there was a bit of beer left in the bottom piece of the bottle, so, as a dedicated ticker, I had to rate Aroma of bourbon, caramel, vanilla, malt, dark fruits. Flavor is sweetish (yet not VERY sweet), fruity, caramel, vanilla, a vinous note, wood. Seems rather light for a bourbon-barrel Barley Wine. Very nice, but not great. Definitely need to try again.
Dark caramel color with a thin head. The aroma is loaded with vanilla and wood, caramel and roast malt. The flavor is similar. Very full bodied and very warming.

Bottle at the March Libertine Bottle Share. Pours a copper to brown with no head. Aroma is burnt sugar, oak and booze. Taste is sweet and bourbon forward. Caramel and some slight bitterness that I cant describe well on the finish.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: On tap at Mikkeller Bar. It pours a dark brown/ruby color with a khaki head. The aroma has lots of bourbon, red fruit, nuts, sweet vanilla, caramel, cherry, raisin and fig. The flavor is pretty much the same. The alcohol presence is strong, but the body is a bit thinner than expected. The carbonation also seems kind of low, but gets more prickly in the finish. Nice, balanced nutty barrel notes as well. Overall, pretty tasty, but not one of the best BA barleywines Ive had on account of the weak mouthfeel. Easier to drink than most though, I will give it that.

On tap at Mikkeller Bar, SF. Pours clear copper with a tan head. Aroma is brown sugar, vanilla, caramel, bourbon, and bread. Flavour is caramel, oak, bourbon, bread pudding, dark dried fruit, vanilla, and spices. Moderate body. Light carbonation. Excellent barrel aged barleywine.

On tap @ City Beer Store, San Francisco - CA. Color: dark brown beer with no carbonation and no head. Smell: high caramel and sweet domination with malt and toffee notes. Really impressive nose, alcohol finish. Taste: nice caramel and toffee taste. Really oily sensation on mouth with malt finish and alcohol presence. Aftertaste: barrel notes and toffee with alcohol. Really impressive beer ! A must to try !

(En fût à la brasserie): Les malts texturés se tortillent dans la vanilline chaude. Jai limpression de boite une fondue au caramel. Le corps est moyen à riche et la sécheresse dalcool est bien presente, le monstre est à la hauteur.
Bottle shared with friends. Aroma is hoppy notes with bourbon and vanilla. Flavor is similar. Big and bold, not much else to say. It still had some hop character behind the barrel treatment.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2015 Deep rich ruby brown pour of 2013 vintage. Looks incredible. Almost no head. Big bourbon and vanilla aroma on this one, which is super exciting. Taste is sweet up front then port then vanilla and some toasty. Very dry finish. Bit thin on the palate. Good barley wine but not nearly as big wow factor as the barrel aged wee heavy.
Bottle pours murky brown with low white head. Aroma is sweet malts and bourbon. taste is similar with a medium body and dry bourbon and malt finish, well done

From a bottle (75 cl), courtesy of _angst_. Shady amber, low head. Caramelly, bready malt aroma with piney and citric hops, and well integrated barrel cognac aromas. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Semi dry, medium bitterness.

Bottle received in trade. Thank you bytemesis! Pours wooden brown with a rather small goldenish offwhite head that doesnt leave much trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and malty with caramel, toffee, charred wood, coconut milk, moist soil, bourbon alcohol and hints of hay. Taste is sweet, slightly bitter and malty with caramel, biscuits, sweet bread, charred wood, coconut milk, hay, soil and hint of liquorice root. Mouthfeel is fat, round, creamy, slightly boozy and near full bodied. Finish is slightly sweet, slightly bitter and malty with caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, charred wood, moist soil, roasted coconut, hay and bourbon alcohol. Yum-a-dum!

Bottle at An afternoon of Skulls, Scotsman and Speedway 141129. Deep amber/brown beer with a nice beige/brownish head. Vanilla aroma, figs, raisins,, toffee, biscuits, caramel, prunes, cream, citrus notes. Malty caramel flavor, raisins, figs, licorice, grapes, some warming alcohol. Really nice.
Bottle shared at capitol beer. Pours Brown with white head. Taste of brown sugar. Malts and oak

750ml bottle (2012 edition) in a tulip. Pours deep brown with a lacy, cream-colored head. Aroma of bourbon and oak and light vanilla, caramel and toffee and notes of chocolate and nuts from the malts, hints of dark fruits, some alcohol, a little bitterness, and some dough. Flavor the same with a great blend of the strong malts and the bourbon barrels. Average texture. A really good beer.

Picked this bottle up at Alesmith. Pours a dark murky brown with a modest tan foam. Foam dwindles to just the rim and no lacing. Figs, brown sugar, raisins, and alcohol presence make a complex and warming brew. The toffee aroma is sweet and the body full. Dark fruits round out the finish which is slightly dry, but leaves you wanting more. I had this with a piece of pumpkin bread. Thoroughly enjoyable.

Bottle from Brouwers, via Dean. Pours a dark black-brown, little to no tan head. Aroma oaky, vanilla, some dried fruit. Body full and smooth with a strong, oaky bite in the back end. Too hot for my taste, but I get why people dig it.

Bottle from the Station. 

A: Dark brown; mahogany. Big fluffy creme colored head. Lacing. 

N: Toffee, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, pine, earth, butterscotch, pineapple, biscuit, walnut. Raisin. 

T: Big sweet barleywine. Some bitterness to balance,but this is a big sweetie.

M: Treacly, heavier body. Big alcohol, as one might expect. 

O: The beer which Mother of All Storms wants to be. Plenty of barleywine notes enhanced by delicious bourbon. Bra-vo.

750ml shared by Brad. Big ups! Big boozy caramel aroma. Foamy off-white head on top of a burgundy amber brown body. World Class, big barrel tones. Excellent malt depth. Perfectly executed beer. No alcohol harshness, no overbearing booze. Phenomenal Barleywine. Smooth bourbon caramel candy. Solid.
Fantastic barrel aged beer. Had at the brewery with audrey. Was happy as a clam. Smooth taste with little alcohol taste. Really awesome

"Newest release. Pours significantly darker than the base BW. Wonderful aroma of bourbon, vanilla, oak, caramel and hops. I though the hop presence of the bw might be a game changer, and it was, lending a great complexity to this beer despite the longtime in barrels. Taste is everything the aroma was plus a little earthy nuttiness, bourbon heavy but not dominant. This was a loooong time whale and was not a let down."

Bottle from a trade. Pours a coffee brown with tan head. Aroma is nice, some vanilla, oak, coffee, with some caramel. Taste was delicious, flavors of coffee, caramel, vanilla, and booze all intermingling together nicely. A notch below King Henry, very very good. Glad to have finally tried this one.

golden orange 1 finger bubbly head fades slowly. Smells of smoked meat, cigars, tobacco and cloves. taste is sweet, boozy, lots of cough medicine and a mix of sweet potato / yam, brown sugar, boozy whiskey and honey.
Deep chestnut. Small off white head. No lacing. Bourbon aroma and malt. Bourbon vanilla taste. Boozy.

Bottle at Schouskjelleren, july 1st 2014. Copper brown body with a thin tanned head. Aroma is malty with oak, bourbon, toffee. Sweet caramel taste with alcohol notes, bourbon, dark fruits, light vanilla sting in finish. Warm boozy aftertaste with balanced sweetness and a light roast character. Quite excellent!

750 ML bottle

Dark murky brown color, light tan head. 
So well balanced nose. Caramel, bourbon, oak, dark fruits, figs, vanilla, and coconut. 
Taste matches nose quite well. Very sticky and jam like. Sensational barrel variation
Bottle at Craigs. Pours reddish brown, nose is toffee, vanilla, coconut, taste is quite rich caramel, vanilla, sweet, dry.
Bottle, thanks Craig. Nice mahogany red with off white head. Aroma oof bourbon, vanilla, oak. Taste of vanilla, toffee, wood, coconut. Sweet and bitter. The barrel influence is quite full on

Murky light brown, soft ringed head. Vibrant sweet Caramac Bourbon. Choppy oak. Initial taste is bursting with sickly sweet Bourbon, without actually kicking much Bourbon kick. Injection of soft sticky malt, parked up esters. Finishes bile and acidic. Bottle, Fancy Al Fresco Tasting
Color caoba oscuro con espuma marfil. aromsa de bourbon, maiz, pasas y madera. Cuerpo denso con inicio dulce de pasas y bourbon, al que le sigue una madera seca y muy equilibrada. Excelente.

Bottle @ RBSG Grand Tasting. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty woody bourbon vanilla and caramel aroma with hints of dark fruit. Fruity malty woody dark fruit and caramel flavor with hints of bourbon. Has a fruity malty woody bourbon and dark fruit finish.
Bottle - Vintage 2005 - Vinous and barell notes. Cloudy copper with a small head. Light caramel and big barrel notes. Mellow but surprisingly potent for the age.

Shared at RBSG 2014. Thanks Drew! Killing a big want. Nose is a dried fruit and sherry marriage in heaven. A thick chewy viscous vanilla yummy bomb. A slight bit warming that borders on hot but chill. Some grape thing going on too. Very chill and good.

Bottle from Belmont Station. Pours orange brown with a modest beige head and a fruity bourbon aroma. There is an earthy caramel malt flavor with lots of oak and a nice bourbon finish. Melts in your mouth.

2012 bottle. Pours a cloudy medium brown without a head. Aromas of raisins and figs with a hint of caramel. Taste is sweet with a light bourbon heat. With there was more vanilla however. Very subdued and well incorporated. Always well done Alesmith.
Bottle shared thanks to artmcd8. Poured dark amber with thinning head. Aroma of bourbon dark fruit. Light carb med bod. Less bourbon in the taste smooth sweet raisins.

A- pours a hazy, ruddy and slightly rosy amber. One finger of light tan head that dissipates quickly. Virtually no lacing. S- strong bourbon, caramel malts, vanilla, toffee, brown sugar, ripe gala apple, banana esters, wood, raisins, dates. Light pecans. Mostly expected, but well received. M- medium to heavy oily body with a medium to heavy sharp palate with good burn. T- bourbon, caramel and vanilla are once again very forward. Middle is alcohol, see's toffee, apples, zinc, a medley of dried fruits and some toasted oak. Ending is efficient but lingers. Hop notes. Citrus pith, grass, and a light smoke. Some dirtiness.

2006 bottle, purchased at the brewery a long time ago when I had the time and money to chase down highly hyped special releases. I have to say, as I work my way through a collection of barrel aged beers, that, generally speaking, I dont think bourbon barrel aging is a good idea. Still, this beer handles it much better than most. Nice amber-brown color with almost no head - do brewers deliberately bottle their barrel aged beers to be flat, or are they just not able to nail the bottle conditioning? The aroma is overwhelmed by bourbon, but some nice caramel malts do make it through. The taste is more interesting than the smell, with a touch of acidity, some pleasant fruitiness/winey flavor and a restrained sweetness, not much hop flavor but enough bitterness to give it some grip. Its smooth and not overly heavy, with a full texture, but, and maybe Im missing the point of a high-gravity, barrel aged barley wine, I would like some bubbles. Alcohol is not prominent at all for a beer this big, and the bourbon does not overpower the taste the way it did the aroma. Its a warm, satisfying, well balanced beer, but personally, I prefer the beer without the barrel aging.

2013 bottle - Pours ruby red with amber and a ring of tan head. Nose is boozy, brown sugar, and yeasty bread. Too sharp for my liking. Taste is real smooth and sweet, with caramel and toffee and a warm finish. Smooth and slick, pretty thick with medium carbonation.

750 ml Bottle of 2012 Vintage. Hazy golden amber pour topped with sudsy beige foam. Dark fruits and caramel dominate the aroma along with some toasted oak, dried fruit and toffee in the mix. The flavor starts with an aggressive dose of caramel malt, citrus rind and brown sugar backed by notes of bourbon, raisin and vanilla. Moderately thick and creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation and a final serving of candied citrus and oak in the finish. Different but equal to the base beer with a hefty barrel alcohol presence.

P: Dark amber color with a big tan head that goes away quick. S: Seem muted, some oak, chocolate, brown sugar, and caramel. T: Light toffee notes, oak, bourbon, caramel, dark fruites. M: Medium (almost light) with medium carbonation. O: Great beer, glad I finally got to try this one.

This is a mostly clear red with just a little wisp of head. This has a huge coconut nose w/ a very sherry-like oxidized character. This is thick and sticky on the palate but somehow comes across more a s velvety than heavy. It is nice and creamy with loads of dark, dried fruit notes. It comes off as a little boozy but thats OK because it really lends itself to slow sipping.

2007 113/449

A- Pours a deep ruddy brown color with a very small light brown head that fades quickly.

S- Absolutely amazing. Huge raisin and brown sugar notes, vanilla, bourbon, caramel.

T-Very decadent and rich. Lots of brown sugar, dark fruits with deep caramel and bourbon notes.

M- Thick with medium carbonation.

D- The taste doesnt quite deliver what the smell promises but non the less I think this vintage is drinking very well right now.

2005 bottle 69/225. Pours clear reddish alber with no head. Aroma of raisins and nuts and a stringent alcohol heat. Sweet body, no carbonation, heavy on the alcohol. Taste is lots of bourbon vanilla and some nuts. Mediocre, not worth the hype.

2012 bottle from trade with zathrus. Thanks dude! Pours dark reddish amber with a small yellowish khaki head. Aroma of hard candies (like the kind on the outside of candy apples), brown sugar, toffee, biscuits, a small bit of vanilla, oak, and some whiskey. Flavor is very similar to the regular version up front: hard candy, toffee, biscuity sweetness. But the finish provides something new: notes of vanilla, oak, and bourbon. The difference from the regular is rather subtle and maybe that's because this has been in the bottle for 2 years or so. Slick and thickish bodied, low carbonation, but not quite syrupy. This is a very good beer, but I must say, I am a bit disappointed at the lack of barrel influence here. I was expecting a big oaky vanilla infusion here that I didn't really get.
2013 750ml bottle pours a hazy brown with an off white head. Bourbon is big in this one. Great malt vanilla molasses and bourbon taste.

Excellent bourbon fueled BW, but the flavours havent integrated and intwined themselves in the same way the wee heavy BA did. Still this is hefty, robust drinking. Ripe fruits, caramel, vanilla and bourbon.
Sampled 2012 in a big bottle. Pours like a whiskey with a minimal carbonation. Drinks smoothly with a crisp malty base. Very well created.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2014 2012 vintage. (3/6/14) Been really looking forward to cracking this open! Pours a beautiful dark ruby reddish amber. Small, strong spongy off-white head, full lasting with some lace. Aroma is phenomenal. Base beer and barrel character blend seamlessly. Towards malty sweet, but wonderfully balanced. Smooth bourbon, vanilla, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, dried dark fruits, oak. Complex. Hop character dissipated, some grapefruit and pine hang in the shadows. Bigger medium to Lighter full body. Slick. Semi creamy. Smooth. Sweet. Warming and tickling with bourbon through a long finish, with the back of the tongue and throat rousing to life. All that while still remaining super drinkable. Complex and cohesive. Majestic
very sweet, malt, dark fruit, bourbon aroma. very delicate but bold at the same time. Taste is similar. Spot on. Light but full flavored. smooth. delicious. definitely worth a try.

From bottle at The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours very hazy brown with a beige head. Aroma of bourbon and toffee. Near full bodied. Flavor is bourbon, brown sugar, oak. Its a bit oily. Gets very oaky. And finishes surprisingly dry. Good. Great even.

Bottle @ Dean to Mouth tasting, courtesy of kermis. Pours a clear brownish beer with a small, off white head on top. Aroma of bourbon, malts, licorice, sugar and molasses. Slightly alcoholic in the aroma. Flavor has some red fruits, really sweet, barrel characters and faint bitterness in the background. Long sweet aftertaste, very nice balance. Very nice brew!

Damn damn damn. Because of a internet connection failure I lost my rating. Remember the beer to be a bit alcoholic, but some hops, slightly sweet, some liquor. Medium to full body and carbonation. Very nice.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2014 Deep amber with a white, thin, lacy, lasting, head that hugs the edges. Smells of sweet grains with caramel, malt, vanilla and bourbon backing. Some alcohol. Medium oily frothy body with a bit of burn on the tongue. Tastes of alcohol with a caramel and vanilla note but the burn consumes my mouth. Some roast, oak, vanilla, and a bit of toffee. The burn is a bit strong for me. Lots of sweet caramel that fills the mouth.

Bottle shared at THT thanks to kermis. Pours cloudy reddish. Aroma is alcohol, red fruits, caramel, wood, bourbon and booze. This is one incredibly beer. So much flavour. Quite sweet and quite bitter. Full bodied with a long finish.

Bottle at the "Lets celebrate the fact that Dean is already the Mayor of M&S Den Haag even though its only been open for 24 hours tasting!". Poured a hazy medium to dark amber with a a round glass hugging white head. The aroma is rich malt ripe fruit yeast. The flavour is medium to strong bitter with a big alcoholic liqourice bitter palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation and a long heart warming alcoholic bitter finish.
Bottle @ tasting. Thanks Kermis! Aroma is huge bourbon, big caramel, malts, oak, vanilla. Flavour is caramel, vanilla, oak, bourbon etc etc LRAB.

Bottle shared at the "Lets celebrate the fact that Dean is already the Mayor of M&S Den Haag even though its only been open for 24 hours tasting!", thanks to trade with Alen. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, malt, brown sugar. Flavour is light heavy sweet and bitter. Full bodied with soft carbonation.
Poured medium reddish brown with no head. Aroma of bourbon sweetness, dark fruit. Full body, flavour of sweet caramel and fudge, berries.

sample @THT courtesy of Kermis.
thin white head. Hazy amber pour. Some bourbon. Some sweetness. Awesome!

Bottle thanks to Daniel. Pours a near clear deep amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is full of sweet grains with a good amount caramel and notes of vanilla and bourbon backing. Flavor is full of caramel and vanilla with a nice oakiness with a bit of bourbon and a touch of toffee.

Bottle pours cloudy medium brown with thin yellowish head. Aroma of bourbon, malts, oak, hops. Initial swallow quite hoppy, after that the hops fade and taste predominantly caramel, toffee, bourbon and slight oak. The hops do add a zest and mouth tingle. Great thick palate.

Hazy brown-orange pour. Nose is tangy dark and citrus fruit with oaky bourbon. Flavor is tart/tangy bourbon-soaked dark fruit. Fairly dry oak finish with a little vanilla. Lots of tangy bourbon and wood notes. Medium road mouthfeel - slightly beefier than the rye version. Overall a quality beer, but bourbon barrel characteristics are more in your face and not as blended as in the rye version.
Bottle shared by adnielsen and Lenincat. Aroma is dark fruit and bourbon. Flavor is strong bourbon, boozy and finishes with dark fruits.
Bottle shared @ Armins - Carmel color pour with almost no head. Big booze and toffee nose. Hot, but big caramel, toffee and vanilla - slightly sweet and then finishes boozy. Nice.
Botella 75cl. En el Lúpulo Feroz. Esto es entrar por la puerta grande en el mundo de las barley wine. Me comentan que es posible que no la encuentre mejor. Veremos...
2012 Bottle, incredibly solid barleywine. Lots of unsweetened english barleywine, touch of vanilla, toffee, not much bourbon.

Bottle, 2012 vintage, 11/27/2013. Pours deep brown, ruby highlights, frothy light tan head fades to splotchy film on the surface. Aroma is sweet toffee, raisins, fruity malts, slight roast/bitter character with brown sugar, vanilla and bourbon. Taste is fruity dark malts, chocolate toffee, mild roast and spicy hop kick blending with boozy finish, vanilla and strong bourbon character. Heavy body, drinks smooth despite the strength. Delicious.

Bottle thanks to somebody, rating from my backlog. The smell is sweet, toffee, alcohol, caramel, fruits, and really really nice. The look is cloudy, beige colored and and brownish in color. The taste is sweet, fruits, alcohol, toffee, caramel. Nice, great feel.

750 ml bottle to half-pint glass (shared by TheBeerSommelier; thanks Matt!). 2009 vintage. Looks good; a cloudy copperish brown with thin off-white lacing. Smells good too; malty with notes of bourbon and caramel. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. Good beer!

Bottle, Thursday mini-tasting. Pours hazy red amber with a small tan head and decent lacing. Aroma is vanilla, oak, bourbon, molasses, toffee, and something a bit of that I could not place. Flavor is medium plus sweet, lightly bitter with some zestiness. Rich flavored, but the barrel is clearly driving the ship. Medium body, silky mouthfeel, quite a bit of heat from the ABV.

Pours mahogany with low to no off white head
Aromas of bourbon, cherries, butterscotch, caramel, muscavado, alcohol
Lovely taste of butterscotch, scottish yeast, bourbon, sugar, warming alcohol
Palate is sweet fullbodied with a great bourbon rich ending

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poirs murky mahogany. Aroma is raisins, honey, muscovado sugar, caramel, burnt sugar, figs, dates, plum, bourbon. Taste is caramel, bourbon-marinated raisins, figs, plum, muscovado sugar. Aftertaste is bourbon and vanilla. Freaking absolutely perfect!! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours murky mahogany amber with low light tan head. Aroma of muscovado, butterscotch, nuts, dates and plums. Taste is incredible! Big initial sweet followed by butterscotch then light balanced alcohol bitter with bourbon and vanilla. Very warming. Rich, creamy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ Alesmith. Pours deep amber brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet malt, caramel, toffee, booze, oak, vanilla and dark fruits. Taste is sweet malts, bourbon notes, vanilla, oak, caramel, and toffee. Full bodied, decent carbonation and a great Barley Wine!

pours unclear dark red-brown with a nice light beige head, some retention and nice lacing. dark fruitiness, boozy fruits - bourbon soaked dried fruits, vanilla bourbon, some roasted malts - chocolate. sweetness. moderate carbonation, medium body - oily, syrupy, very nice grassy-peppery finish. very good bw. much enjoyed!

Bottle (750 ml). Thanks to vissai for this one! Dark amber with a small/medium beige head and come lacing. Aroma is of oak with vanilla, bourbon and caramel. Taste is moderately sweet with bourbon, vanilla, toffee and caramel. A nice warming heat from the alcohol in the finish. Full bodied. Low to moderate carbonation. Textbook barrel-aged Barley Wine. Very well done by AleSmith again. Drinkable for the style.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours deep amber with burgundy reflects. Aroma is of malt, sugar, caramel, alcohol, bourbon. Taste is of malt, sugar, caramel, butterscotch, alcohol, very slight bourbon. Palate: Full bodied. Overall: Nice sugar: not too cloying. Alcohol not well hidden, but I dont think its supposed to be. Would not drink a whole bottle, but this is a very good sipper.

$30.00 bottle from Alesmith brewery, July 2013. Pours cloudy dark amber. Malt aromas with some burbon. Boozy caramels and brown sugars with some vanillas, and of course burbon. My bottle has experienced oxidation. This may have came from the barrel. Alcohol burn in the finish. Overall I was expecting more. I know every batch is different, maybe another vintage will be better.

Bottle. Clear dark copper pour, brandy like. Aroma of burnt maple, toffee, caramel with rich vanilla bourbon notes. Taste is sweet, intensely caramelized malts, rich sweet flavors even though the beer itself isnt very sweet feeling of the palate. Another big ale gem by Alesmith, who have these styles down to a t.
Complex full flavored and fun to drink. Lots of caramel, mollases, bourbon, oak, vanilla, and some hoppiness that adds balance to the back end. A sweet and delicious slow sipper.
Bottle sampled at a tasting. From notes. Bourbon with caramel, vanilla, baking spices and dried fruits. Awesomely good brew.
Wow this barrel aging is fantastic, so sweet and caramelly with good hop bitterness to prevent it from being a diabeetus bomb

Clear amber with a small pale head. Aroma is honey, vanilla, bourbon, apricot, orange peel. Slightly syrupy mouthfeel, smooth and well balanced on the palate. Taste is bourbon, vanilla, honey, dates. Nicer than the regular version

UPDATED: APR 3, 2014 Bottle: Thanks, Kevin! Seedy copper, overtly muddled brown and opaque with a long lasting, khaki colored foam. Sticky, deep aroma; prune, raisins, caramel, toffee, tons of bourbon and woody oak with some brown sugar and sweet grape in the finish. The intense sweetness of the aroma balances the heavy bourbon and oak punch nicely. Taste is grapes and prunes, lacquered in a mixture of brown sugar, bourbon, and spicy oak staves. Quite hot, quite sweet. It finishes with heavy bourbon, boozy oak, slightly burn coffee, sweet prunes, and brown sugar. Viscous, heavy, thick, and creamy. Very nice beer, but pretty damn strong... Get ready.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2015 Pours a murky tamarind with very little head. Aroma of brown sugar; bourbon; caramel. Sweet taste, with dark fruits and brown sugar galore. Slight notes of oxidation with some floral, bitter hop presence at the end. Medium body, slick texture that feels a little on the thin side. Overall: good, but not nearly as impressed with this as Id hoped (I guess thats what I get for having preconceptions).

Bottle at Craftheads. Red brown colour with small bubbly gold head. Aroma is lots of booze, floral, sweet, raisins. Taste is lovely, sweetness, booze, fruity raisins, wood, full bodied. Very nice. Leaves a long fruit boozy linger in the mouth. Very easy to drink in spite of the %.

Brownish caramel color, initially fizzy, good lacing. Sweet butter caramel aroma, figs, cherry. Flavor is similar but the whiskey comes through more prominently plus some chocolate. A little warm but overall a great beer.

Aged Bottle shared by Dave at a tasting, pours lightly hazy amber with small but lasting off white ring of head. Not much lacing. Aromas of vanilla bean, oak, roasted malt, caramel crunch, and rich booze. Taste is much of same with rich oak and whiskey, dark malt, vanilla, wood. Body is smoother than silk, medium mouth. Easiest 11% beer you will encounter.

2,000th rate. Woo! 750 ml bottle poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a darker mahogany with a beige head of foam. The aroma has big booze, herbal hops, licorice, dedehydrated raisins. Taste has a big boozy, dry sweetness to it that lingers on the palate for a very long time. Man, this is a great barrel aged barley wine. Glad I opened it for this occasion.

Bottle, 75cl. A hazy, dark amber beer with a small, dense, light beige head. The aroma has a light bourbon touch, weak enough to make me like it, with some sweetish malts, dried fruits, alcohol, piney and resiny hops, hints of oxidation and some caramel. Its too warming on the palate actually, but in a nice way. Low on carbonation, in a pleasant way, full body. Lots of nice flavors too, caramel sweetness, resiny hops and bitterness, some notes of the bourbon barrels, vanilla, oak and booze, with a touch of oxidation. Dried fruits too. It finishes with a long bitterness and sweetness, the alcohol warmth kicking in adding an extra dimension. Overall, its a really, really fine beer, lots of lovely flavors and aromas, the barrel aging just added a nice touch to the beer. Still, I think I prefer the regular edition. 130823

Bottle. Pours deep amber with an off white head. Aroma of malt, bread, some oxidized notes, dried fruits and caramel. Flavor is sweet and malty with some vanilla, bourbon, spicy notes , warning and slightly boozy alcohol with some caramel and dropped fruits. Full body, average carbonation.

Bottle 750ml @ Hotel Room, Hacienda Hotel LAX, El Segundo, CA
Pours hazy dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, toffee, vanilla, oak, dried fruits and alcohol. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light to medium bitter with a long warm, vanilla, oak, toffee and fruity finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat.
2013 vintage. Pours clear copper with a medium head. Aroma is great: vanilla, caramel, toffee, chocolate, booze. Flavor follows with a bourbon finish. Very good.

Bottle @ Armins apartment, courtesy of Steve_0. Pours a hazy reddish orange appearance with a tan head. Rich coconut, caramel, spicy, a touch fruity, sweet aroma. Chewy, rich caramel, somewhat herbal, toasted malty, fucken boozy, oaky, delicious flavor. All kinds of good stuff.

Bottle at Armins shared with friends. Pour is clear caramel with a big cream-colored head and good lacing. Roasty, caramelly, bready, woody, coconut, bourbon, raisins, figgy, pruney, earthy, and doughy aroma. Taste is big malt, brown sugar, caramel, bourbon, vanilla, bread, somewhat earthy, grassy, nutty, coconut, a touch of grass, and alcohol on the backend. Sticky mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Tasty, but I prefer the regular version more.

750 ml bottle shared by northernbrews. A top want knocked off. Pours a cloudy amber with a nice small head that fades to a ring. Awesome rich aroma of oak, vanilla, caramel candy, toffee, and light bourbon. Taste has big bourbon barrel flavor but the base beer remains very noticeable too. All the aroma show up plus some red and citrus fruit. Nice warming finish, very smooth. Medium body. I prefer the regular version a little more because I love hops but this version is awesome too.
Holy crap, absolutely amazing brew thanks to GT2 and his friends, beautiful caramel color smells like sweet sugar, heaven

This rating is Vintage 2013. The 2005 version I had last year was one of the best beers I have ever tasted. I didnt rate it unfortunately. Poured from 750 ml bottle. Pours about the color of iced tea with just a bit of beige head. Aroma is lots of alcohol and some coconut notes. Taste is some vanilla, coconut, dried fruits and a nice alcohol burn at the end.

Bottle at Sour & Bitter #2. Clear hazelnut brown wit a small off white ok lacing head. Toffee, caramel, sherry, light bourbon notes, honey, dark dried fruits, alcohol. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Medium body, oily/creamy texture, soft/flat carbonation. Needs more body to balance the alcohol.
Memory of taster @ the brewery. Very bourbon aroma and flavor, but not overwhelming. Rich and thick, the alcohol is cut by the everpresent bourbonosity. Woof!

2012 bottle sampled at Kurts Blarneywine tasting on 3/16/13. Clear copper pour with a medium tan head. Complex aroma of vanilla, caramel, toffee, chocolate, bread and bourbon. Malty flavor all the way through with accents of caramel and chocolate before a slightly warm bourbon finish. Outstanding.

Poured on draft from Brewery. Very dark amber with minimal white head. Sweet bourbon and fruit nose. Smooth vanilla, bourbon, and fruit taste along with carmel notes. This would be my favortie barleywine to date. Elite.
Pours dark ruby/brownish with a persistant cream head. Aroma is figs, dark fruit, brown sugar, and barrel. The taste is bourbon, brown sugar, and caramel. Delicious

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Murky dark amber with low carbonation. Aromas are of muslix, light molasses, stewed fruit, and bourbon barrel. Very heavy pale malts in the mouth along with caramel malts, woody bourbon and whole wheat toast. Super chewy body. Solid, but a bit too heavy heavy for me.

Pours a dark amber color with light tan head.  Aromas of caramel, vanilla, toffee with the same flavors coming through in addition to some oak and bourbon.  Very good! One of the best ba barleywines Ive had.

Yes sir this is damn good, 2012 vintage. Pours amber in the glass with very thin head. Aroma is perfect barleywine notes with caramel and alcohol then smooth malty notes. Flavor is awesome with minimal hops and great hints of barrel and caramel malts. Palate is thick and sticky and perfect. Overall this is right up my alley.

Nice. Getting bourbon up front. Really nice toffee back end. Just a tad too much alcohol heat. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle @ S&B#2. Pours clear amber with a minimal off-white head. Aroma is sweet with candy toffee, raisin, toasted malt, dried fruit, nut and some hops. Taste is medium + sweet and light bitter. Body medium, texture is syrupy, carbonation is soft. Finishes warming.

Bottle from Alesmith.  Pours a clear mahogany with an eggshell head.  Aroma is caramel, vanilla, apple, alcohol and light bourbon.  Taste is sweet with some bitterness and light barrel.  Medium bodied.  Good.

Man, this stuff is great.  Probably the best barleywine Ive had.  Smooth, sweet, with a lot from the bourbon (chocolate, vanilla, boozy) and a sweetness from the barleywine.  Drinks easy, way too easy for the booze level.  A fantastic sipper if you get the chance.

Pours semi transparent dark brown with almost no head just some bubbles. The nose is big caramel, some vanilla, maple, honey and rich English toffee. Phenomenal.  The taste is very high sweet, low bitter with a fairly balanced finish. The texture is soft and creamy. The body is heavy and finish is long. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Alesmith.
Aroma: lots of caramel and toffee, chocolate malt, toasted oak and spirits, some spirits and a touch of booze.
Appearance: somewhat murky brown pour, tan head leaves some decent wisps of lacing.
Taste: bold and rich malt character, lots of toffee and hints of roast and chocolate, sweetness is present but tempered by the alcohol and bitterness.  Warming alcohol but not at all hot, nice vanilla and oak flavors from the barrel, bourbon notes complement the beer nicely.
Palate: full body, low-medium carbonation, a bit of a warming alcohol finish.
Overall: very well-made beer, well-integrated flavors and nice complexity.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on 4/15/2013.
Appearance: Pours a dark caramel. 
Aroma: Aroma of caramel, oak, chocolate.
Taste: Light bitterness, caramel, chocolate, oak, lots of depth.
Palate:Medium body, slick.
Summary: A really exception barleywine - lots of depth of flavor, well made. Impressive.

Rating # 1300. Vintage 2004. Bottle 42/227. Sorry but I dont remember who I got this delicious beer from. Unclear dark amber body with no head. Aroma is raisins, plums, oak, winegusm, light tobacco notes, candy sugar, toffee, light hops. Flavour is raisins, plums, oak, vanilla, oak, light hoppy, caramel, burned sugar, malt. The alcohol thickles on the tongue. The carbonation is very soft. Very complex and very delicious brew. Damn!!!
A solid ba barleywine in every sense of the word, perfect blending of caramel malts nad oak/vanilla.

Sample from a 2012 bottle at the Blarney Wine tasting on 03/16/2013: The beer is a murky reddish-brown color with a medium foamy off-white head that recedes steadily. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of earthy malt, oak and dark fruits. Full-bodied with flavors of roasted malt, caramel, oaky vanilla and raisins. The finish is bourbon and vanilla. Good beer all around.
Aroma of sweet toffee, caramel, candied cherry, and slight pine hope.  Pours red and thick enough.  Tastes wonderful with hoppy BW notes, sweet potato, toffee, and slight cherry syrup.  So good.
750 ml. bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with a small biege head.  Aroma of caramel, malt, dark fruit, and bourbon.  Taste is caramel, bourbon, apples, malt, and alcohol. Excellent!!

UPDATED: APR 5, 2013 February 16, 2013 - bottle via trade with Chris.  Muddy brown with nice head.  Aroma was delicious bourbon, caramel, and wood.  Taste was consistent with aroma and some vanilla.  Very smooth and medium to full bodied.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Bomber. Deep murky brown pour with a big foamy head. Wood, caramel, vanilla, and bourbon on the aroma and taste. Awesome beer.
2012 Vintage.  Dark amber pour with an off white and creamy head.  Aroma of bourbon, toffee, vanilla and some cocoa.  Taste is similar and damn good.   Lovely and tasty beer!

Pours unclear murky dark amber. The aroma and flavor are pretty hot for being a fresh bottle, but it isnt as thin as you would expect for the barrel age. The aroma brings some sweet chocolate malts, as well as the flavor. The body is just right as well.

Sample, green bottle, 750 ml, 2005, from and with Philippe Boutin; eye: dirty brown, opaque, no effervescence, no head, no lacing; nose: woody, bourbon, butterscotch, slight salty, slight soy sauce, light spices, anise; mouth: woody, bourbon, butterscotch, slight salty, slight soy sauce, light spices, anise, alcohol, light soy sauce, dry finale in bourbon with woody presence, full body, not much carbonation, mildly bitter and sweet, lightly alcoholic texture; overall: quite fine
 
FRANÇAIS
 
Échantillon, bouteille verte, 750 ml, 2005, de et avec Philippe Boutin; il : brun sale, opaque, pas deffervescence, pas de mousse, pas de dentelle; nez : boisé, bourbon, caramel écossais, très léger salé, très léger sauce soya, léger épices, anis; bouche : boisé, bourbon, caramel écossais, très léger salé, très léger sauce soya, léger épices, anis, alcool, léger sauce soya, finale sèche en bourbon avec présence boisée, corsée, peu carbonatée, moyennement amère et sucrée, texture légèrement alcoolique; en résumé : bien bon

Bottle Vintage 2007 248/449 at The Barley Wine Tasting, London - many thanks to Paul. Pours fuzzy ruby with a creamy, yellow-beige head. Dark, sweet bready malt nose with faint, leathery fruits. Rick cake and bread flavor, medium to big sweetness, slight dirt, dry fruits, caramel, some leather and earth, small alcohol presence. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Faintly warming finish with toasty caramel, dirt, dried and leathery dark fruits, well toasted bread, some faint burnt wood and malts. Very tasty stuff.

Pint on tap.  Color is cherrywood, translucent, great lacing.  Aroma is light, a little bit of alcohol, some cloves.  Strong alcohol taste (its 11% after all), its bitter as well, but equally sweet.  A very good barleywine, but not my favorite.  The aging is interesting, but there are a few regular BWs I like better.

13/XI/12 - 75cl bottle @ De Hopduvel (Gent) - 2007 vintage!, bottle # 41/449 (2012-1270) Huge thanks to Bobochamp for sharing the bottle!
Clear red brown beer, small to no head. Aroma: lots of sugary caramel, sweet, alcohol, quite some bourbon and vanilla, pretty spicy, raisins, wood notes, dried figs and dates, little vinous red wine, cranberries. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: caramel sweetness in the start, then surprisingly bitter and spicy, vanilla, wood, little sourish, red grape skin. Aftertaste: sweet caramel again, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol, little bitter, spices (nutmeg?).

A murky hazed brown ale with no head. In aroma, a musty caramel malt with vinous notes light soy, musty and smooth. In mouth, a sweet dark fruit, piney hops, plums, a bit of dust, nice alcohol, decent. Tasted with GRM, Puskinwow, Boutip, Ian, Mike on Sept. 7 2012.

75cl, Vintage 2007, at 11%Vol, Bottle 41/449 (hand-written), exclusive American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, sweet/alcoholic and slightly woody/malty/bitter, not too heavy, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Big thanks to Ryan for breaking this out of his cellar. 2004 vintage. This bottle is way past its prime, flavor is gone, as is the carbonation. However it was an incredible experience to be able to have tasted this.

Bottle, we think from 2005 but might have been  - thanks to Boutip for opening up this with my BA Wee Heavy - was nice to try both of them. Cloudy mahogany with limited white head. Right of the start you can tell this is old with a nice musty aroma; then you get fruit, butterscotch, light smoke, toffee, vanilla, light oak, old sweet malt. Smooth, no carbonation, you can tell it would have been fuller bodied but age has mellowed it too much, sweet, very tasty.

Bottle: Poured a deep copper color ale with a light foamy head with minimal retention and minimal lacing. Aroma consists of sweet toffee and caramel notes with light cardboard notes and light bourbon notes. Taste is also dominated by sweet toffee notes with some caramel malt with some bourbon notes though not as much as expected. Light cardboard notes a re revealing that this bottle might be past its prime. Bourbon notes are not as dominant as I would have expected. Body is a little bit thin for style with medium carbonation and no apparent alcohol notes. Fell a bit short of my expectation but good nonetheless. It would be interesting to try a fresher bottle next time.

Bottle @ THE Barley Wine Tasting. Massive thanks to Scopey (I think). 2007 bottling. The pours murky reddish brown with a tiny off-white head. The nose is light blue cheese, toffee, cranberry fruits and caramel-covered wood. Not a huge, expressive nose. The taste is mild toffee, some mocha powder. Meaty cherry pit. Mildly sweet. Medium body, a bit salty. Perhaps a bit of oxidization has given the beer a bit of an earthy character. Overall, quite nice.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 Bottle at THE Barley Wine Tasting, August 2012. 2007 vintage, number 268/449. It pours deep mahogany brown, with a thin beige head. The nose is caramel, toffee, oak, earth, vanilla, chocolate, meatiness and some mustiness. The taste is wood, earth, light roast, toasted coconut, salted caramel, alcohol warmth, cherry, grape, raisin and nut, with a dry, warming finish. Full body (but not to the same level of King Henry), fine carbonation and good balance between sweetness and savoury earth/wood notes. Not as sweet as the un-BA version, which suits me just fine.

750 ml bottle brought to the tasting by bsuedekum- thanks, Blake! We traded for this one, so I will take a shred of the credit. 2007 vintage, bottle 255/449. Pours a hazy amber with a small off-white head that lasts for a surprisingly long time before staying as a ring. Aroma of vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, dried fruits, coconut, oak, and a good amount of bourbon throughout. Same goes for the flavor, which also has notes of oak, tobacco, vanilla, dark fruits, toasted malts, coconut, and brown sugar. Blake thought there was some cardboard-like oxidation starting to show in the flavor but I didnt think it was there much at all. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, toasty mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Really well-done bourbon barrel barley wine thats drinking awesome right now. I dont see the 2007 getting better (especially if Blake is right on his note), so Id open it this year if you still have one.

Bottle shared by Peter and Blake!  Pour is slightly hazy copper/ brown  with small ring of tan foam. Aroma and flavor loaded with coconut, brown sugar, toffee malt, faint alcohol and a touch of spice. Really nice very little oxidation at all

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad!

The beer is hazy and appears brown to amber in color. The head is off white and thin. The aroma is bold and offers malt, booze, toffee, dark fruits. Very enticing. The flavor really delivers. A delightful beer to sip and savor. Medium to full bodied. Very malt forward and well balanced. A gem - I definitely recommend this beer.

Serving type: bottle

Thanks Brad, served in a snifter. At the time of the review, this is the #5 beer on the "Top Beers - American Barleywine" list on beeradvocate.com.

Beer is dark amber / brown, hazy with a thin off white head of small bubbles. No lacing, low carbonation, low carbonation.

Beer smells like barrel, oak, wood, malt, raisins, plums. Smells really nice, in my face, strong, aggressive.

Beer is medium in body, creamy with a mildly dry finish. It is strong, fruity and malty. Very strong, nice finish, a very good beer.

Serving type: bottle
Bottle courtesy of - you guessed it - ygtbsm94, thanks!  Deep clear amber color, flat. Aroma  of perfume base, brandy and caramel candy. Taste is hot and spiced mulled apple brandy. Interesting.

2006 vintage

A: Poured a murky brownish color with a light sediment presented, a light tannish cap

S: Still has a quantifiable amount of old spent oak spirals, Earthiness, light vanilla and booze

T: Still had some light residual sugar sweetness, with old wood, light vanilla and pinch of raisin remains

M: Medium to big body at this age with lower carbonation, some fading flavors, light booze and stickiness

O: Good but it is peaking IMO or has recently peaked

Tap at brewery a few weeks back.  Pours a nice mahogany hue with a thin layer of tan foam.  Aroma mainly of earthy peaty malts, strong bourbon, and vanilla with lesser notes of caramel, thick molasses, and dried fruit.  The hoppiness of fresh Numbskull has really faded in the nose here.  Flavor has significant bourbon, dark sticky toffee, chocolate-covered maraschino cherries, wet oak, and brown sugar.  There is still some hop-tinged flavors here, but the barrel is dominant.  Mildly sweet and a bit soft on the palate.  There is a tingle of alcohol in the finish -- it warms but does not distract here.   Excellent execution on this one.  Glad to finally get to try this one...it completes my trifecta of barrel-aged Alesmith classics, along with the equally amazing BA Speedway and BA Wee Heavy.  (474, 692)

2007 vintage, bottle #407/449, split with manuchampions and uhlan. Pours a dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma of wood / bourbon barrels, toffee / caramel, dark fruits and candied sugar - the barrels dont really shine on the nose... but they do on the tongue. Flavour of bourbon barrels, toffee, dark fruits, vanilla, alcohol and finishes with light fruity sweetness and booze. Wood barrels and done very well, but adds a vanilla character that very slightly detracts from the complexity of the base beer. Most excellent, though an extremely slow sipper.

2003 Vintage, Bottle #110/223
Tasted in late November 2011 from a capped 750mL bottle shared by unclejedi at his birthday tasting, massive thanks on this rarity, Jim.  Pours clear blood orange with some tan lace that quickly disappears.  The nose is earthy English-style barley wine with caramel, toffee, burnt brown sugar, and bourbon notes of vanilla and coconut.  The flavor is full of caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and the oaky bourbon coconut and vanilla, with the sweetness nicely balanced by the earthy yeast.  The body is full with an oily texture, light carbonation, and a long caramel and oaky bourbon finish.

In short: A fantastic big fruity dark beer with a nice wood barrel presence.  Great beer.
How: Bottle 750ml.  2007 version released in 2009, bottle #88 of 449.  Consumed when a little over than 2 years of age.  Bottle sent to me by kegbear, thanks a million Craig
The look: Cloudy burgundy body topped by a small beige head
In long: Nose is only moderately bourbonny and with plenty of raisins and dark fruits.  This beer smells like a world-class Abt that would have been aged in bourbon barrels for a short period of time.  Just from the aroma I knew it was going to be something special.  Taste has lots of vanilla, raisins, dark fruits, earthy three roots, caramel, notes of milk chocolate, light scented notes similar to garden flowers.  Body is full and the carbonation is very lively and thats totally unexpected from a barrel aged big american beer.  Its hard to put into words why a beer like that works so well, listing a bunch of flavor elements doesnt do it justice and is almost meaningless.  Everything just worked perfectly in this beer.  I went through a full bottle and it was pure pleasure and I would have loved to drink a second bottle immediately, something I almost never say about a barrel aged big beer.  This was one of the greatest big beers Ive ever had, what else can compare?  I went to my PC to google "greatest big beers" but I googled "greatest big boobs".  Dont be surprised if I dont see me on ratebeer for the next few months.

This one grew on me the more I drank it. Poured a dark brown color, and had a flavor I find hard to describe (deep hop flavor mixed with a dry finish?). It was enjoyable, but expensive, and not one I would have often.

Bottle brought by me, 2007 Vintage, #117/449. Poured into Darkness snifter.

A - Pours a dark brown/reddish color, cream ring, with random whisps on top.

S - Dark fruits, huge oak/barrel, ever so slight hoppy bitterness, caramel, burnt sugars. Perhaps a little more oak-forward then I prefer but otherwise, pretty good.

T - Dark fruit, caramel, oak/barrel. Smooth booze, nice caramel sweetness, and the oak isnt quite as strong as the nose (thats a good thing). 

M - Light to medium (a bit too thin), good carbonation, and creamy sweet finish.

O - I think I actually prefer the regular 2007 over the Barrel-Aged version. Perhaps a bit too much oak for me in this one. I wonder how the other years stack up to 2007? I guess Ill have to try them and see.

Hazy dark amber color/ beige head. Vanilla, whiskey, alcohol fuel, caramel, wood aromas. Medium bodied with light co2. Sharp spicy pit fruit, alcohol fuel flavors with sweet vanilla, caramel, whiskey--2004 bottle 147/240
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: From notes, 2007 bottle. May 2010 tasting, with a HUGE thank you to Greg.  Pour is a very slightly hazy red brown with almost yellow highlights, with a light tan head that fades quickly.  No lacing.  Aroma is dominated by brown sugar, caramel, and molasses sweetness.  Taste is much the same, with the sugar sweetness dominating any malt or hop profile that could be hiding in there.  Far too sweet for my tastes, but a decent example of a BAd beer.  Would have benefited from a larger hop profile...

2002 edition bottle generously shared at the RBSG grand tasting. Pours a cloudy amber with frothy beige head. Aroma is hot and full of oxidized sherry and butterscotch. Flavor is boozy up front with sweet toasted coconut and butterscotch, Marshmallow fluff in the finish with loads of booze. A bit too much for me. Massively sweet and hot.

Bottle 117/49, big 10 thanks to Sean9689 for providing an rare top RB tick, I had mine set aside for buttpirates but who knows whats going on with that... dark murky brown with a surprising amount of carbonation, light tan ring... the nose is pretty nice but light, doesnt smell barrel aged at all, a solid regular barley wine, a bit of hops and caramel... taste is oak and hops, solid nothing special... Id have again but dont give up much

750mL 2002 ed bottle #36/225 at RBSG 2011 in Philly. The pour is a cloudy, muddy pinkish amber with a medium yellow/beige head forming. Nose is very nice candied tamarind, curacao, sweet brandy. Soft maple comes through with no hints of oxidation or that "orange mint" character that older and hoppy barleywines take on. Very beautiful nose. Taste is very soft with a silky palate. Maple and sweet strawberry come through with mild whiskey heat and present woody bitterness. Very beautiful mouthfeel. Lovely. Would love a bottle to myself ;)

This poured a medium brown color with a decent sized head considering this is an 02 bottle. Aroma was lots of bourbon, some toffee and sweet malt. Flavor is a good bit over bourbon, definately dominating this one but the sweetness of the base beer is still there. I think the bourbon helped hold up the underlying barleywine. A bit oxidized but still darn good.

2005 thanks to whoever at Daves going away a longtime want.

Probably a little past its prime, a bit oxidized and slightly heavy on the bourbon sweetness but some really good things going on underneath, cocoa, caramels, some nuttiness and a bit of fruit.  Not perfect, but still very good and I hope they revisit this in the near future.
05 X/4XX.  Not sure who to thank for this but thanks.  Beer of the night for me, granted I left early and didnt take notes during any of my 50ish ticks, this was the star of the evening for me.

750ml bottle from brewboy1. Have had this in the cellar for a couple of years and have been unable to find a good time share with some people so why not on Mothers Days. Pours hazy toffee colored brown with small tan head. Aromas of bourbon, dark fruits, dark malts, toffee and vanilla. Flavors bourbon, vanilla, dark fruit, toffee, and bit of brown sugar. Still has the alcohol warmth. Mouthfeel is a tad thin, but still has held up nicely. Probably a little past its prime. Still a damn good beer. Love these BA barley wines.

750, capped and foiled. 04. #31/245.  Drank in 2008.  Thanks to Old_Mr_Crow!  Been a while, but I remember this being extremely bold of a beer.  Lots of bourbon, caramel, hints of booze, nuts, and a load of oak.  All this - blended together and aged PERFECTLY.  Serious treat business right here!

Served from a bottle at OTMs 1st Anniversary AleSmith tasting. 2004 vintage. The appearance is a mearky red hued brown. I got the bottle end of the bottle so it had a lot of the yeast in in. The aromas are malty with a oak edge. Caramel would be the most forward but not a sweet caramel. The flavors are similar with a really tasty malt profile, notes of caramel, grainy, brown sugar, not too much other fruit or distinct to me notes. The mouth is full bodied. Smooth, with a bit of chunkiness from the yeast. A really solid brew. Would love to try a touch fresher.

A: The pour is sort of a murky dark amber/copper color with a small khaki head.

S: Moderate amounts of bourbon hit the nose followed by some vanilla and brown sugar.  Plenty of caramel and toffee sweetness to go with it.  No real hop character left at this point.

T: Surprisingly restrained bourbon from an Alesmith barrel aged beer.  Vanilla, brown sugar, toffee, and bread, and yes, some bourbon too.  Perhaps a hint of chocolate, and definitely a bit oxidized.

M: Medium to full in body with a moderate carbonation.

O: Not as overwhelming as some of the other Alesmith barrel aged releases, but quite good, and significantly better than the previous times Ive had it.

Bottle 80/227.  2004 batch released in 2006.  Aroma has notes of dark dried fruits, raisins, vanilla, wood, licorice, sweet bourbon, sherry, port and sweet dark fruits.  Rusty dark red amber hue with no head.  Flavor is very sweet and medium bitter.  Palate is full bodied and oily soft with a little alcohol burn and just like its base numbskull it is still kind of thin for a barely wine.  Overall a real interesting barley wine.  Fruity and not bitter at all.  Some oxidation but not nearly what there should be at this age.  The bourbon has relaxed a bit and blended very well with the sweet malt backbone.  The hops are mostly gone but the honey notes of the Numbskull are still there.  Overall a very sweet and complex beer that keeps getting better as it warms.  Really going to enjoy this one for the rest of the night.  Just what I needed.  ;^)

Thanks to Photekut for busting this out at the Jackie Os release.  Served in a SAVOR snifter.  Pour yields a caramel-colored brew with a thin off-white head.  Nose is filled with aromas of sweet bourbon, caramel, and a bit of brown sugar.  Mild booze there as well.  Flavor is not as integrated as the nose, but the bourbon is nice.  Not terribly bourbon-forward, however.  Also some caramel, sweet bread, and some brown sugar intermingling.  Mouthfeel is medium with low carbonation and a bit of booze in the finish.  A very excellent brew that I had wanted to try for some time.  Thanks again, JR.

Cloudy Mahogany.  Aroma is an enormous dose of toffee, sherry-like oxidation notes, barrel vanilla, chocolate orange, Black cherry fruit.  Flavor is very boozy, it coats the tongue.  Flavor is Sherry, oxidation, faded dark fruit - dates, prunes.  Breadiness is apparent in the center and then fades to a nutty sticky finish.  Epic, a little over the hill, but still delicious.

2006- Thanks jblauvs. Garnet mahogany pour with no head. The nose is MASSIVE caramel toffee, prune, really nice sherry like oxidation  (I usually despise oxidation), port, cherry, raisin, fig, plum, vanilla bourbon, nutty yum yums, and titillating booze. The flavor holds massive caramel, toffee, huge ethanol, almond, dark fruit, and the slightest orangepeel acidity. The palate is thick and rich, but the age has gotten to the thickness slightly. Silky and viscous with a coating finish.

2006 bottle thanks to jblauvs. Cloudy mahogany pour with a small bubbly off-white head. Aroma holds gargantuan notes of toffee, caramel, sherry and port, further vinous notes, and fantastic dark fruit presence including plum and raisin, and Chambord/Cointreau booze. Great vanilla bourbon notes, bread, and almond as well. Flavor has more great caramel, sweet oxidation, and dark fruit. Increased presence of sweet nuttiness, like marzipan. Some more orangy, fruity booze presence carries through both the flavor and palate, where the tongue is coated with silky alcohol, almost as if there are "legs" in your mouth. A touch past its prime, but still delectable.

2005 bottling. At this point it is a sweet syrupy sipping kind of beer. Lots of molasses and raisin aromas with a touch of alcohol left burning the nostril a bit. Flavor is mostly raisin adn a little alcohol again. Not loving how this has aged at this point unfortunately. Any hops that were here are toast at this point. Maybe I wasnt ready for what to expect with this at the time of drinking. Lucky to have tried it though.
05 bottle courtesy of Cesar.  Dark brown pour.  Sweet malt, dark fruits, caramel, oak, and boozy flavors....

2007 bottle shared by drgonzo, thanks Paul. Pours dark brown with off-white head. The aroma was sweet malts, dark fruits, toffee, oak, and bourbon. The flavor was the same but a bit boozy with a very nice warmth to the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2011 750ml bottle 2007 vintage, number 315/444.  Pours a hazy, translucent, deep caramel brown with a thin, eggshell head.  Aroma is right on point, shoe leather, caramel, malt, maple, french oak, a touch of brandy, raisins, dried cherries, mulling spices, dried orange peel, potpourri, some stale bread.  Smells a touch oxidized and thats OK by me.  Flavor is toffee, brown sugar, caramel, malts, leather, oranges, vanilla, fruit cake, cherry, raisin, sherry, wood pulp.  Lots of barrel but the beer holds up well.  Very well balanced, worthy of all the hype.  I was happy to celebrate my wedding day with this gem.

07 bottle courtesy Amy - thank you!  Initially healthy tan head quickly fades out over lively carbonated, caramel brown beer.  Aroma is deep, rich bourbon over caramel, marshmallow, oak, and slight raisin.  Perfectly balanced and rich aroma.  Taste is heavy bourbon up front followed by faded hops, caramel, and a sweet raisin/date and barley wine tinge through the finish.  Very minor alcohol just after the finish.  Body feels a touch thin.  The taste does not meet the expectation presented by the aroma but its still a very enjoyable, rich sipping beer.

Bottle shared by Dmac. Thanks! 180 of 208. Pours dark caramel toffee. Strong nose of plum, raisin, caramel, toffee and barrel. Taste is rich toffee, raisin, deep caramel, dark fruits, vanilla and light barrel. Some warming alcohol in the finish.

From notes:

2006 vintage. Huge thanks to BigFish for sending this years ago in one of my first trades.

Pours a very dark, murky chestnut brown color with a one finger off white head that quickly fades into a thin ring. Sporadic splotches of lacing left behind.

Slightly earthy, leathery malt aroma with hints of biscuit, caramel and toffee. This is accompanied by an amazing bourbon barrel character. Plenty of earthy oak with a healthy dose of bourbon/booze and a very prominent vanilla character in the nose.

Medium bodied with the perfect balance of earthy, leathery malt, caramel/toffee, alcohol sweetness, bourbon, oak and vanilla. Slight heat but overall the alcohol is excellently masked with subtle warmth in the finish. The malt profile is earthy/leathery yet sweet with hints of caramel, toffee and hazelnut. Theres some slight bitterness that adds balance and an incredible bourbon barrel presence. Earthy oak as well as a huge bourbon and vanilla character. I cant believe that Alesmith was able to create such a delicious bourbon flavor without it tasting like a hot, booze bomb. The ABV is incredibly well masked resulting in a delicious, extremely quaffable beer.

This is the best BA barleywine that Ive had to date and I wish I that I had more bottles.

2007 edition, bottle #443/449, courtesy of the very generous, cbkschubert. thanks, craig! i figured new years eve was the perfect time to open this one as its about 3 years old now and boy was i right. pours a gorgeous, hazy, chestnut brown with hints of red and a full, dense, off-white head leaving beautiful lacing. aroma is absolutely amazing with huge sweet notes of toffee, pralines, maple bars, and woody vanilla with notes of brandy, spiced raisins, and black cherry backed by pine esters and citrusy fruit-cake. flavor is fantastic as well, this is where the bourbon barrels really shine, adding a sharp, spicy, oaked presence to balance the sweet toffee, dark fruits, and butterscotch cake with hints of dried cherry, vanilla, and orange peel on the back end. palate is full bodied, beautifully carbonated, and smooth with a sweet, warming sensation on the finish. overall, another fantastic barrel aged brew from alesmith.

750ml bottle via trade, 2007 vintage.

Very nice appearance - deep clear reddish-brown in color with a one-finger light beige head leaving a thick bubbly ring.

The aroma is excellent.  Sweet sticky caramel malt, maple syrup, and big woody -bals.

The flavor is great, unapologetic and complex.  Somewhat sweet, but not too much so, with caramel, toffee, and maple syrup.  Barrel aging is evident with a big woody presence and some sherry-like oxidative notes. 

Fairly full-bodied with soft carbonation and slight syrupiness.
